acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: These items came to the Library of Virginia in a transfer of court papers from Lynchburg.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: Buckingham County probably was named either for the English county or for the duke of Buckingham. According to some sources, however, the name came from Archibald Cary's tract of land called Buckingham, on what was then Willis's Creek. It was formed from Albemarle County in 1761.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Buckingham (Va.) apprentice indenture binding the son of Betsy Scott, a free woman of color, to Clough Amos, 1812 Dec. 14. Scott's son, Wilson Scott, was apprenticed to Amos to learn "the art and mystery of a waterman in navigating [the] James river."

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Buckingham County is one of Virginia's Lost Records Localities. Additional Buckingham County court records may be found in the Lost Records Localities Digital Collection in Virginia Memory on the Library of Virginia web site.
